   - EP study today- complicated by perforation, pt asystole for 10s,

   intubated, Hct was 17 --> s/p 4U pRBC transfusion.  Fem art line was

   fasciotomy. Received 1200cc IVF and 1U pRBC (5U total)Suggest watching
   for ARF, checking serial CKs, potassiums.
   - d/c'd BP meds overnight
   - ordered repeat TTE in AM

   Assessment and Plan
 PERICARDIAL EFFUSION WITH TAMPONADE
 PERIPHERAL VASCULAR DISEASE (PVD) WITH CRITICAL LIMB ISCHEMIA
 AIRWAY, INABILITY TO PROTECT (RISK FOR ASPIRATION, ALTERED GAG,
   AIRWAY CLEARANCE, COUGH)
 CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE PULMONARY DISEASE (COPD, BRONCHITIS, EMPHYSEMA)
   WITH ACUTE EXACERBATION
 MYOCARDIAL INFARCTION, ACUTE (AMI, STEMI, NSTEMI)
   78 yo F with COPD presents with anterior MI and failed PCI on a tight
   proximal lesion currently on medical management, s/p pacemaker
   placement complicated by RV perforation and right leg ischemia.
   RV PERFORATION: Pt with tamponade after perforation of RV during pacer
   placement. Drainage of ~1L of blood. Drain in place. Repeat ECHO did
   not show further tamponade physiology.  Pt received total of 5U pRBC
   and Hct stable.
   - repeat ECHO today
   - Hct check q8
   - Active T&S
   - cont to monitor hemodynamics closely
   .
   RIGHT LEG ISCHEMIA: Distal pulses were lost after placement of right
   femoral a-line. s/p left SFA thrombectomy, femoral endarterectomy,
   right fasciotomy. +dopplerable pulses post-procedure. CK wnl
   - appreciate vascular recs
   - cont to check dopplers
   - monitor wound site
   - trend CK
   - no anti-coagulation given RV perforation
   FEVER/HYPOTENSION/LEUKOCYTOSIS: Spiked this am to 102 and is now
   hypotensive with MAPs ion the 40
s. Possible etiologies included sepsis
   related to lines or new hardware versus ischemic bowel (esp given abd
   slightly tense)
   -cont vanc
   -gebin neo to keep MAPs>60
   -blood cx, urine analysis/urine cx sent
   -CXR
   -check lactate
   -monitor fever curve
   -place central line
   RHYTHM: H/O paroxysmal Afib but presents with slow afib and AV
   dissociation.  Pt underwent pacemaker placement that was complicated by
   RV perforation. CXR neg for PTX
   - appreciate EP recs
   - cont vanc post-pacer placement
   - cont to monitor on tele
   - will need PA/Lat when stable
   CORONARIES: Pt transferred for NSTEMI and is s/p ccath that  focal LAD
   lesions that could not be intevened . Pt was being medically managed
   and stable.  BP meds were held secondary to hypotension
   - cont ASA and plavix given stable Hct and minimal drainage from
   pericardial drain
   - holding coreg, Imdur and amlodipine
   - repeat ECG this AM
   .
   PUMP: EF 60-70%, although increased left ventricular filling pressure
   (PCWP>18mmHg) on TTE. Pt received 5U pRBC and 2-3L IVF in the OR
   yesterday. CXR did not show gross overload.
   - TTE today
   - hold on diuresis for now given hypotension
   - hold  Coreg
   .
   RESPIRATORY FAILURE: Pt intubated after tamponade. Last ABG
   7.36/36/163/21. Currently resp status is stable. Pt with COPD and was
   on prednisone for COPD exacerbation.
   - Cont current vent setting, wean as tolerated
   - change to IV steroids
   - cont albuterol/ipratropium Q4
   - repeat CXR today
   -f/u pulm recs
   .
   FIRM ABDOMEN: Concern for ischemic bowel given recent RV perf and
   tamponade event. Lactate currently normal.
   -c/s general surgery
   -KUB this am
   .
   COPD: Pt on prednisone for flare. Pulm was consulted prior to RV
   perforation. Recommended non-con CT for eval for right hilum. Question
   as to whether pt truly as COPD or other process given recent worsening
   over the last year.
   - cont prednisone
   - cont albuterol/ipratropium
   - non-con CT when stable
   .
   HTN: Pt hypotensive this AM. BP meds were d/c overnight.
   -cont neo for pressure support
   - IVF prn
   - repeat ECHo this AM
   - holding BP meds
   .
   FEN: NPO,  nutrition consult, replete lytes prn
   CONTACT: [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Known lastname **] [**Telephone/Fax (5) 7029**]
   CODE: FULL (reversed DNR/DNI for procedure, will need to discuss
   options and goals of care with family)
   ------ Protected Section ------
   Cardiology Teaching Physician Note
   On this day I saw, examined and was physically present with the
   resident / fellow for the key portions of the services provided. I
   agree with the above note and plans.
   I have also reviewed the notes of Dr(s). [**Name (NI) 7030**].
   I would add the following remarks:
   History
   EP procedure yesterday with placement of atrial pm for SSS complicated
   by RV perforation resulting in need for intubation adn
   pericardiocentesis.   Placement of Femoral arterial line complicated by
   right leg ischemia requiring urgent thrombectomy and fasciotomy.
   This AM febrile 102, hypotensive requiring Neo, abd distention noted.
   No [**Last Name (un) 126**] elevation or EKG change.
   Received total of 5 U PRBC.
   Physical Examination
   Mod abd distention.
   Medical Decision Making
   Will recheck echo and pull pericardial drain.
   Vascular surgery to follow and gen surgery consulted re change in abd
   exam.
   On Vanc and Gent.
   Above discussed extensively with family member, next of [**Doctor First Name 23**] or health
   care proxy.
   Total time spent on patient care: 60 minutes.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 78-year-old female with a complex medical history, including:

1. Pericardial effusion with tamponade: The patient underwent pericardiocentesis and had a significant amount of blood drained from the pericardial sac. The patient received 5 units of packed red blood cells and has a stable hematocrit.
2. Peripheral vascular disease (PVD) with critical limb ischemia: The patient has PVD and has lost distal pulses in the right leg. The patient underwent thrombectomy and fasciotomy, and the pulses are now Dopplerable.
3. Myocardial infarction (MI) with acute coronary syndrome (ACS): The patient had an MI and was treated with PCI, which failed due to a tight proximal lesion. The patient is currently on medical management and has a pacemaker in place.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and was on prednisone for a COPD exacerbation.
5. Fever and hypotension: The patient has a fever of 102°F and is hypotensive, which may be related to sepsis or ischemic bowel.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Cardiac tamponade: The patient has had a significant amount of blood drained from the pericardial sac, and there is a risk of recurrent tamponade.
2. Ischemic bowel: The patient has had a recent RV perforation and tamponade event, which may have caused ischemia to the bowel. The patient has a firm abdomen, and there is concern for ischemic bowel.
3. Sepsis: The patient has a fever and is hypotensive, which may be related to sepsis.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and has a history of COPD, which may worsen over time.
5. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient has a pacemaker in place, and there is a risk of cardiac arrhythmias.
6. Renal failure: The patient has received a significant amount of IV fluids and has a history of PVD, which may increase the risk of renal failure.
7. Wound complications: The patient has had a recent surgical procedure and has a wound in the right groin, which may be at risk for complications.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Repeat echocardiogram to assess for cardiac tamponade and cardiac function.
2. Monitoring of hemodynamics and fluid status.
3. Antimicrobial therapy for sepsis.
4. Monitoring of wound site and Doppler pulses.
5. Trending of creatine kinase (CK) levels to assess for ischemic bowel.
6. Monitoring of lactate levels to assess for sepsis.
7. Consideration of non-con CT to evaluate for right hilum pathology.
8. Continued management of COPD with oxygen therapy and bronchodilators.
9. Monitoring of cardiac rhythm and arrhythmias.
10. Consideration of cardiac catheterization to assess for coronary artery disease.

The patient's family member has been informed of the patient's condition and plan of care, and the patient's healthcare proxy has been consulted.

   .

   on prednisone for COPD exacerbation.
   - Cont current vent setting, wean as tolerated
   - cont prednisone 60mg daily
   - cont albuterol/ipratropium
   - repeat CXR
   .
   FEVER/HYPOTENSION/LEUKOCYTOSIS: Spiked this am to 102 and is now
   hypotensive with MAPs ion the 40
s. Very likely this represents sepsis.
   Cxs sent.
   - sent blood cx and urine cx
   .
   COPD: Pt on prednisone for flare. Pulm was consulted prior to RV
   perforation. Recommended non-con CT for eval for right hilum. Question
   as to whether pt truly as COPD or other process given recent worsening
   over the last year.
   - cont prednisone
   - cont albuterol/ipratropium
   - non-con CT when stable
   .

   - IVF prn

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 78-year-old female with a complex medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), acute myocardial infarction (AMI), and peripheral vascular disease (PVD) with critical limb ischemia. The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Pericardial effusion with tamponade, which has been drained and is currently stable.
* PVD with critical limb ischemia, which has been treated with left SFA thrombectomy, femoral endarterectomy, and right fasciotomy.
* Acute respiratory failure, which is being managed with mechanical ventilation.
* Myocardial infarction, which has been medically managed and stabilized.
* Hypotension, which is being managed with IV fluids and vasopressors.
* Fever, which is being investigated as a possible sign of sepsis.
* Leukocytosis, which is being monitored.
* Hypokalemia, which is being treated with potassium supplements.
* Elevated creatinine, which is being monitored.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Continued tamponade physiology, which could lead to cardiac arrest or death.
* Worsening respiratory failure, which could lead to respiratory arrest or death.
* Sepsis, which could lead to multi-organ failure and death.
* Myocardial infarction, which could lead to further cardiac complications.
* PVD, which could lead to further limb ischemia and potentially limb loss.
* Hypotension, which could lead to organ dysfunction and death.
* Hypokalemia, which could lead to cardiac arrhythmias and potentially cardiac arrest.
* Elevated creatinine, which could lead to acute kidney injury and potentially chronic kidney disease.

The patient's current medications include:

* Aspirin
* Plavix
* Coreg
* Imdur
* Amlodipine
* Prednisone
* Albuterol
* Ipratropium
* H2 blocker

The patient's laboratory results include:

* Hemoglobin: 13.3 g/dL
* Hematocrit: 37.8%
* Platelet count: 110 x 10^9/L
* White blood cell count: 14.0 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 0.8 mg/dL
* Potassium: 4.0 mmol/L
* Sodium: 143 mmol/L
* Chloride: 115 mmol/L
* Bicarbonate: 21 mmol/L
* Glucose: 118 mg/dL

The patient's vital signs include:

* Temperature: 36.7°C
* Heart rate: 61 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 107/42 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 20 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 100%

The patient's current treatment plan includes:

* Mechanical ventilation to manage respiratory failure.
* IV fluids and vasopressors to manage hypotension.
* Potassium supplements to manage hypokalemia.
* Antibiotics to manage possible sepsis.
* Non-con CT scan to evaluate for right hilum process.
* Repeat ECHO to monitor cardiac function.
* Trend CK levels to monitor for signs of cardiac injury.
* Monitor wound site for signs of infection.
* Discuss antibiotic use post-pacer placement with EP team.
* Continue ASA and plavix given stable Hct and minimal drainage from pericardial drain.
* Hold Coreg, Imdur, and amlodipine.
* Repeat ECG this AM.
* Continue prednisone and albuterol/ipratropium for COPD exacerbation.

 PERIPHERAL VASCULAR DISEASE (PVD) WITH CRITICAL LIMB ISCHEMIA
 AIRWAY, INABILITY TO PROTECT (RISK FOR ASPIRATION, ALTERED GAG,
   AIRWAY CLEARANCE, COUGH)
 CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE PULMONARY DISEASE (COPD, BRONCHITIS, EMPHYSEMA)
   WITH ACUTE EXACERBATION
 MYOCARDIAL INFARCTION, ACUTE (AMI, STEMI, NSTEMI)
   78 yo F with COPD presents with anterior MI and failed PCI on a tight
   proximal lesion currently on medical management, s/p pacemaker
   placement complicated by RV perforation and right leg ischemia.
   RV PERFORATION: Pt with tamponade after perforation of RV during pacer
   placement. Drainage of ~1L of blood. Drain in place. Repeat ECHO did
   not show further tamponade physiology.  Pt received total of 5U pRBC
   and Hct stable.
   - repeat ECHO today
   - Hct check q8
   - Active T&S
   - cont to monitor hemodynamics closely
   .
   RIGHT LEG ISCHEMIA: Distal pulses were lost after placement of right
   femoral a-line. s/p left SFA thrombectomy, femoral endarterectomy,
   right fasciotomy. +dopplerable pulses post-procedure. CK wnl
   - appreciate vascular recs
   - cont to check dopplers
   - monitor wound site
   - trend CK
   - no anti-coagulation given RV perforation
   FEVER/HYPOTENSION/LEUKOCYTOSIS: Spiked this am to 102 and is now
   hypotensive with MAPs ion the 40
s. Possible etiologies included sepsis
   related to lines or new hardware versus ischemic bowel (esp given abd
   slightly tense)
   -cont vanc
   -cont neo to keep MAPs>60
   -blood cx, urine analysis/urine cx sent
   -CXR
   -check lactate
   -monitor fever curve
   -place central line
   RHYTHM: H/O paroxysmal Afib but presents with slow afib and AV
   dissociation.  Pt underwent pacemaker placement that was complicated by
   RV perforation. CXR neg for PTX
   - appreciate EP recs
   - cont vanc post-pacer placement
   - cont to monitor on tele
   - will need PA/Lat when stable
   CORONARIES: Pt transferred for NSTEMI and is s/p ccath that  focal LAD
   lesions that could not be intevened . Pt was being medically managed
   and stable.  BP meds were held secondary to hypotension
   - cont ASA and plavix given stable Hct and minimal drainage from
   pericardial drain
   - holding coreg, Imdur and amlodipine
   - repeat ECG this AM
   .
   PUMP: EF 60-70%, although increased left ventricular filling pressure
   (PCWP>18mmHg) on TTE. Pt received 5U pRBC and 2-3L IVF in the OR
   yesterday. CXR did not show gross overload.
   - TTE today
   - hold on diuresis for now given hypotension
   - hold  Coreg
   .
   RESPIRATORY FAILURE: Pt intubated after tamponade. Last ABG
   7.36/36/163/21. Currently resp status is stable. Pt with COPD and was
   on prednisone for COPD exacerbation.
   - Cont current vent setting, wean as tolerated
   - change to IV steroids
   - cont albuterol/ipratropium Q4
   - repeat CXR today
   -f/u pulm recs
   .
   FIRM ABDOMEN: Concern for ischemic bowel given recent RV perf and
   tamponade event. Lactate currently normal.
   -c/s general surgery
   -KUB this am
   .
   COPD: Pt on prednisone for flare. Pulm was consulted prior to RV
   perforation. Recommended non-con CT for eval for right hilum. Question
   as to whether pt truly as COPD or other process given recent worsening
   over the last year.
   - cont prednisone
   - cont albuterol/ipratropium
   - non-con CT when stable
   .
   HTN: Pt hypotensive this AM. BP meds were d/c overnight.
   -cont neo for pressure support
   - IVF prn
   - repeat ECHo this AM
   - holding BP meds
   .
   FEN: NPO,  nutrition consult, replete lytes prn

   CODE: FULL (reversed DNR/DNI for procedure, will need to discuss

Based on the patient's progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is intubated and on ventilator support due to tamponade and acute exacerbation of COPD. Weaning from ventilation may be challenging, and the patient is at risk for respiratory failure.
2. Cardiac Complications: The patient has a history of myocardial infarction, and the recent RV perforation and tamponade event may have further compromised cardiac function. The patient's EF is 60-70%, and there is increased left ventricular filling pressure (PCWP > 18mmHg) on TTE. This may lead to cardiac failure, arrhythmias, or cardiac arrest.
3. Sepsis: The patient has a fever, hypotension, and leukocytosis, which may indicate sepsis. The possible etiologies include sepsis related to lines or new hardware versus ischemic bowel.
4. Ischemic Bowel: The patient's abdominal examination is slightly tense, and there is concern for ischemic bowel given the recent RV perforation and tamponade event.
5. Renal Failure: The patient received 5U pRBC and 2-3L IVF in the OR, which may have compromised renal function. The patient's creatinine is 0.8 mg/dL, and the patient is at risk for acute kidney injury (AKI).
6. Electrolyte Imbalance: The patient's potassium levels are elevated (6.0 mg/dL), and there is a risk of electrolyte imbalance due to the patient's medical conditions and treatments.
7. Bleeding Complications: The patient has a history of bleeding complications, including tamponade and RV perforation. The patient is at risk for further bleeding complications, especially with the presence of a central line.
8. Infection: The patient has a central line, arterial line, and femoral endarterectomy, which increases the risk of infection.
9. Pulmonary Embolism: The patient has a history of DVT and is at risk for pulmonary embolism, especially with the presence of a central line.
10. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient has a history of COPD and is at risk for gastrointestinal complications, including constipation, diarrhea, and malnutrition.

The patient's medical team should closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatments accordingly to prevent or manage these potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
 PERICARDIAL EFFUSION WITH TAMPONADE
 PERIPHERAL VASCULAR DISEASE (PVD) WITH CRITICAL LIMB ISCHEMIA
 AIRWAY, INABILITY TO PROTECT (RISK FOR ASPIRATION, ALTERED GAG,
   AIRWAY CLEARANCE, COUGH)
 CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE PULMONARY DISEASE (COPD, BRONCHITIS, EMPHYSEMA)
   WITH ACUTE EXACERBATION
 MYOCARDIAL INFARCTION, ACUTE (AMI, STEMI, NSTEMI)
   78 yo F with COPD presents with anterior MI and failed PCI on a tight
   proximal lesion currently on medical management, s/p pacemaker
   placement complicated by RV perforation and right leg ischemia.
   RV PERFORATION: Pt with tamponade after perforation of RV during pacer
   placement. Drainage of ~1L of blood. Drain in place. Repeat ECHO did
   not show further tamponade physiology.  Pt received total of 5U pRBC
   and Hct stable.
   - repeat ECHO today
   - Hct check q8
   - Active T&S
   - cont to monitor hemodynamics closely
   .
   RIGHT LEG ISCHEMIA: Distal pulses were lost after placement of right
   femoral a-line. s/p left SFA thrombectomy, femoral endarterectomy,
   right fasciotomy. +dopplerable pulses post-procedure. CK wnl
   - appreciate vascular recs
   - cont to check dopplers
   - monitor wound site
   - trend CK
   - no anti-coagulation given RV perforation
   FEVER/HYPOTENSION/LEUKOCYTOSIS: Spiked this am to 102 and is now
   hypotensive with MAPs ion the 40
s. Possible etiologies included sepsis
   related to lines or new hardware versus ischemic bowel (esp given abd
   slightly tense)
   -cont vanc
   -gebin neo to keep MAPs>60
   -blood cx, urine analysis/urine cx sent
   -CXR
   -check lactate
   -monitor fever curve
   -place central line
   RHYTHM: H/O paroxysmal Afib but presents with slow afib and AV
   dissociation.  Pt underwent pacemaker placement that was complicated by
   RV perforation. CXR neg for PTX
   - appreciate EP recs
   - cont vanc post-pacer placement
   - cont to monitor on tele
   - will need PA/Lat when stable
   CORONARIES: Pt transferred for NSTEMI and is s/p ccath that  focal LAD
   lesions that could not be intevened . Pt was being medically managed
   and stable.  BP meds were held secondary to hypotension
   - cont ASA and plavix given stable Hct and minimal drainage from
   pericardial drain
   - holding coreg, Imdur and amlodipine
   - repeat ECG this AM
   .
   PUMP: EF 60-70%, although increased left ventricular filling pressure
   (PCWP>18mmHg) on TTE. Pt received 5U pRBC and 2-3L IVF in the OR
   yesterday. CXR did not show gross overload.
   - TTE today
   - hold on diuresis for now given hypotension
   - hold  Coreg
   .
   RESPIRATORY FAILURE: Pt intubated after tamponade. Last ABG
   7.36/36/163/21. Currently resp status is stable. Pt with COPD and was
   on prednisone for COPD exacerbation.
   - Cont current vent setting, wean as tolerated
   - change to IV steroids
   - cont albuterol/ipratropium Q4
   - repeat CXR today
   -f/u pulm recs
   .
   FIRM ABDOMEN: Concern for ischemic bowel given recent RV perf and
   tamponade event. Lactate currently normal.
   -c/s general surgery
   -KUB this am
   .
   COPD: Pt on prednisone for flare. Pulm was consulted prior to RV
   perforation. Recommended non-con CT for eval for right hilum. Question
   as to whether pt truly as COPD or other process given recent worsening
   over the last year.
   - cont prednisone
   - cont albuterol/ipratropium
   - non-con CT when stable
   .
   HTN: Pt hypotensive this AM. BP meds were d/c overnight.
   -cont neo for pressure support
   - IVF prn
   - repeat ECHo this AM
   - holding BP meds
   .
   FEN: NPO,  nutrition consult, replete lytes prn

Based on the patient's progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) with acute exacerbation. There is a risk of respiratory failure, especially with the current vent setting and the patient's underlying lung disease.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient has a history of myocardial infarction (MI) and has undergone pacemaker placement, which was complicated by right ventricular (RV) perforation and tamponade. There is a risk of cardiac arrhythmias, cardiac tamponade, and cardiac failure.
3. Sepsis: The patient has a fever and hypotension, which may indicate sepsis. The possible etiologies include sepsis related to lines or new hardware, ischemic bowel, or other infections.
4. Ischemic bowel: The patient has a history of RV perforation and tamponade, which may have caused ischemic bowel. There is a risk of bowel perforation, peritonitis, and sepsis.
5. Renal failure: The patient has received 5U of packed red blood cells (pRBC) and has a history of cardiac tamponade, which may have caused acute kidney injury (AKI). There is a risk of renal failure, especially with the patient's underlying cardiac and respiratory disease.
6. Pneumonia: The patient has a history of COPD and has received antibiotics, which may increase the risk of pneumonia.
7. Pulmonary embolism: The patient has a history of cardiac tamponade and has received anticoagulation therapy, which may increase the risk of pulmonary embolism.
8. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient has a history of RV perforation and tamponade, which may have caused gastrointestinal bleeding. There is a risk of gastrointestinal bleeding, especially with the patient's underlying cardiac and respiratory disease.

Based on the patient's current condition, the following plan should be implemented:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs, including blood pressure, heart rate, and oxygen saturation.
2. Continue to administer oxygen therapy and ventilatory support as needed.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status, including electrocardiogram (ECG) and echocardiogram (ECHO) results.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status, including chest x-ray (CXR) and arterial blood gas (ABG) results.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function, including blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine levels.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's gastrointestinal status, including abdominal x-ray (KUB) and stool samples.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's fever and hypotension, and consider antibiotics and vasopressors as needed.
8. Consider consulting with a cardiologist, pulmonologist, and gastroenterologist to optimize the patient's care.

The patient's family should be informed of the potential complications and the plan of care, and should be involved in decision-making regarding the patient's care.

 PERIPHERAL VASCULAR DISEASE (PVD) WITH CRITICAL LIMB ISCHEMIA
 AIRWAY, INABILITY TO PROTECT (RISK FOR ASPIRATION, ALTERED GAG,
   AIRWAY CLEARANCE, COUGH)
 CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE PULMONARY DISEASE (COPD, BRONCHITIS, EMPHYSEMA)
   WITH ACUTE EXACERBATION
 MYOCARDIAL INFARCTION, ACUTE (AMI, STEMI, NSTEMI)
   78 yo F with COPD presents with anterior MI and failed PCI on a tight
   proximal lesion currently on medical management, s/p pacemaker
   placement complicated by RV perforation and right leg ischemia.
   RV PERFORATION: Pt with tamponade after perforation of RV during pacer
   placement. Drainage of ~1L of blood. Drain in place. Repeat ECHO did
   not show further tamponade physiology.  Pt received total of 5U pRBC
   and Hct stable.
   - repeat ECHO today
   - Hct check q8
   - Active T&S
   - cont to monitor hemodynamics closely
   - Maintain MAP >60
   RIGHT LEG ISCHEMIA: Distal pulses were lost after placement of right
   femoral a-line. s/p left SFA thrombectomy, femoral endarterectomy,
   right fasciotomy. +dopplerable pulses post-procedure. CK wnl
   - appreciate vascular recs
   - cont to check dopplers
   - monitor wound site
   - trend CK
   - no anti-coagulation given RV perforation
   RHYTHM: H/O paroxysmal Afib but presents with slow afib and AV
   dissociation.  Pt underwent pacemaker placement that was complicated by
   RV perforation. CXR neg for PTX
   - appreciated EP recs
   - discuss regarding antibiotic post-pacer placement
   - cont to monitor on tele
   - will need PA/Lat when stable
   CORONARIES: Pt transferred for NSTEMI and is s/p ccath that  focal LAD
   lesions that could not be intevened . Pt was being medically managed
   and stable.  BP meds were held secondary to hypotension
   - cont ASA and plavix given stable Hct and minimal drainage from
   pericardial drain
   - holding coreg, Imdur and amlodipine
   - repeat ECG this AM
   .
   PUMP: EF 60-70%, although increased left ventricular filling pressure
   (PCWP>18mmHg) on TTE. Pt received 5U pRBC and 2-3L in the OR yesterday.
   CXR did not show gross overload.
   - TTE today
   - hold on diuresis for now given BP
   - hold  Coreg
   .
   RESPIRATORY FAILURE: Pt intubated after tamponade. Last ABG
   7.36/36/163/21. Currently resp status is stable. Pt with COPD and was
   on prednisone for COPD exacerbation.
   - Cont current vent setting, wean as tolerated
   - cont prednisone 60mg daily
   - cont albuterol/ipratropium
   - repeat CXR
   .
   LEUKOCYTOSIS: Likely reactive in the setting of EP procedure and
   surgery. No evidence of infection. Pt afebrile.
   - cont to trend WBC and monitor for fevers, hold on abx given no source
   of infection
   - sent blood cx and urine cx
   .
   COPD: Pt on prednisone for flare. Pulm was consulted prior to RV
   perforation. Recommended non-con CT for eval for right hilum. Question
   as to whether pt truly as COPD or other process given recent worsening
   over the last year.
   - cont prednisone
   - cont albuterol/ipratropium
   - non-con CT when stable
   .
   HTN: Pt hypotensive this AM. BP meds were d/c overnight.
   - IVF prn
   - repeat ECHo this AM
   - holding BP meds
   .

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 78-year-old female with a complex medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), myocardial infarction (MI), and peripheral vascular disease (PVD). She has been admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) due to pericardial effusion with tamponade, right leg ischemia, and respiratory failure.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory support: Invasive ventilation with a tidal volume of 400 mL and a respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute.
* Hemodynamics: The patient's blood pressure is 107/42 mmHg, with a heart rate of 61 beats per minute. Her central venous pressure is elevated, indicating increased left ventricular filling pressure.
* Cardiovascular status: The patient has a pericardial effusion with tamponade, which was drained in the operating room. She has also undergone a pacemaker placement, which was complicated by right ventricular (RV) perforation.
* Pulmonary status: The patient has COPD, which is exacerbating her respiratory failure. She is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation.
* Renal status: The patient's creatinine level is 0.8 mg/dL, and her blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is 23 mg/dL.
* Neurological status: The patient is sedated and unable to provide a history.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Complete blood count (CBC): WBC 9.1 x 10^9/L, Hct 17%, platelet count 176 x 10^9/L
* Electrolyte panel: Na 135 mmol/L, K 4.1 mmol/L, Cl 100 mmol/L, Ca 7.6 mg/dL, Mg 3.2 mg/dL, PO4 3.9 mg/dL
* Blood chemistry: Glucose 111 mg/dL, creatinine 0.8 mg/dL, BUN 23 mg/dL, troponin-T 2.82 ng/mL

The patient's medical plan includes:

* Continuous monitoring of her hemodynamics and respiratory status.
* Repeat echocardiogram to assess the pericardial effusion and RV function.
* Serial checks of her hemoglobin and potassium levels.
* Monitoring of her wound site and dopplerable pulses.
* Trending of her creatine kinase (CK) levels.
* No anti-coagulation given RV perforation.
* Holding of beta-blockers and calcium channel blockers due to hypotension.
* Repeat CXR to assess for pulmonary embolism.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Acute kidney injury (AKI) due to hypotension and fluid overload.
* Respiratory failure due to COPD exacerbation and mechanical ventilation.
* Sepsis due to bacterial colonization of the pericardial drain or other invasive lines.
* Pericardial tamponade recurrence due to incomplete drainage or re-accumulation of fluid.
* Right leg ischemia progression or necrosis due to inadequate perfusion.
* Cardiac arrhythmias due to pacemaker placement and RV perforation.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status to prevent or promptly address these potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 78-year-old female with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), who presented with an anterior myocardial infarction (MI) and failed percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). She underwent pacemaker placement, which was complicated by right ventricular (RV) perforation and right leg ischemia. She developed pericardial effusion with tamponade, which was drained, and was intubated due to respiratory failure. She also had leukocytosis, likely reactive, and was found to have peripheral vascular disease (PVD) with critical limb ischemia.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and requires mechanical ventilation. Weaning from ventilation should be done cautiously to avoid respiratory failure.
2. Cardiovascular complications: The patient has a history of MI, PVD, and RV perforation. She may be at risk for further cardiovascular complications, such as cardiogenic shock, arrhythmias, or cardiac tamponade.
3. Infection: The patient has a central line and arterial line, which increases her risk of infection. She should be monitored for signs of infection, such as fever, chills, or redness at the insertion site.
4. Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis may be a sign of infection or inflammation. She should be monitored for signs of infection, and blood cultures should be sent to rule out sepsis.
5. COPD exacerbation: The patient has a history of COPD and was on prednisone for a flare. She should be monitored for signs of COPD exacerbation, such as increased wheezing or shortness of breath.
6. Hypotension: The patient has been hypotensive and her blood pressure medication has been held. She should be monitored for signs of hypotension and her blood pressure should be closely monitored.
7. Wound complications: The patient had a right femoral endarterectomy and right fasciotomy. She should be monitored for signs of wound complications, such as infection, bleeding, or necrosis.

Assessment and plan:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and wean her from ventilation as tolerated.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiovascular status and manage any cardiovascular complications that arise.
3. Monitor the patient for signs of infection and take appropriate measures to prevent and treat infections.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's leukocytosis and send blood cultures to rule out sepsis.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's COPD status and manage any exacerbations that arise.
6. Monitor the patient's blood pressure and adjust her medication as necessary.
7. Monitor the patient's wound status and take appropriate measures to prevent and treat wound complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results closely.
2. Continue to adjust the patient's medication as necessary to manage her cardiovascular and respiratory status.
3. Consider sending the patient for non-con CT to evaluate for right hilum lesions.
4. Consider sending the patient for a stress test to evaluate her cardiac function.
5. Consider sending the patient for a pulmonary function test to evaluate her lung function.
6. Consider sending the patient for a nutrition consult to evaluate her nutritional status.
7. Consider sending the patient for a physical therapy consult to evaluate her mobility and strength.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 78-year-old female with a complex medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), anterior myocardial infarction (MI), and right ventricular (RV) perforation during pacemaker placement.

The patient's current condition is complicated by sepsis without organ dysfunction, pericardial effusion with tamponade, peripheral vascular disease (PVD) with critical limb ischemia, and airway, inability to protect (risk for aspiration, altered gag, airway clearance, and cough).

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 101.3°F (38.5°C)
* Heart rate: 83 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 100/50 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 20 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 98%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 13.3 K/μL
* Hemoglobin: 32.7%
* Platelet count: 120 K/μL
* Creatinine: 0.8 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 2.82 ng/mL
* Lactic acid: 1.5 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.1 g/dL
* LDH: 509 IU/L
* Calcium: 7.3 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.9 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 3.3 mg/dL

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Vancomycin, aztreonam, and ciprofloxacin for pneumonia
* Levoxaquin for 10 days
* Pantoprazole for stress ulcer prophylaxis
* Heparin for prophylaxis
* Phenylephrine for blood pressure support
* Albuterol and ipratropium for bronchodilation
* Methylprednisolone for COPD exacerbation
* Coreg, imdur, and amlodipine for hypertension

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Sepsis with organ dysfunction
* Pericardial tamponade
* Pneumonia
* Respiratory failure
* Cardiac arrhythmias
* Hypotension
* Renal failure
* Hepatic failure
* Pancreatitis
* Gastrointestinal bleeding

The patient's ICU care plan includes:

* Continuous monitoring of vital signs
* Frequent assessment of oxygenation and ventilation
* Maintenance of blood glucose levels
* Monitoring of electrolyte levels
* Administration of antibiotics and other medications as ordered
* Monitoring of the patient's response to therapy
* Frequent communication with the patient's family and healthcare team.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 78-year-old female with a complex medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), myocardial infarction, and pericardial effusion with tamponade. The patient has been admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for management of these conditions.

The patient's current status is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated due to respiratory failure. She has a left retrocardiac opacity on chest X-ray and sputum cultures growing gram-negative rods and gram-positive cocci.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has a pericardial effusion with tamponade, which has been managed with drainage and medical therapy. She has also had a pacemaker placed, which was complicated by right ventricular perforation.
* Hemodynamic: The patient's hemodynamics are unstable, with a heart rate of 83 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 100/50 mmHg. She has been receiving vasopressors to support her blood pressure.
* Renal: The patient's creatinine level is 1.0 mg/dL, which is elevated from her baseline value of 0.8 mg/dL.
* Infectious: The patient has a urinary tract infection (UTI) and a pneumonia, which is being managed with antibiotics.
* Gastrointestinal: The patient has a firm abdomen, which is softer today. She has had no signs of gastrointestinal bleeding or obstruction.
* Neurological: The patient has a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 12, which indicates a severe head injury.

The patient's medical complications include:

* Sepsis without organ dysfunction
* Pericardial effusion with tamponade
* Peripheral vascular disease with critical limb ischemia
* Airway, inability to protect (risk for aspiration, altered gag, airway clearance, and cough)
* Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) with acute exacerbation
* Myocardial infarction, acute (AMI, STEMI, NSTEMI)
* Right leg ischemia
* RV perforation

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Continued mechanical ventilation and vasopressors to support her blood pressure
* Antibiotics for the UTI and pneumonia
* Drainage and medical therapy for the pericardial effusion with tamponade
* Pain management with opioids and non-opioids
* Fluid management with diuretics and vasopressors
* Nutrition support with total parenteral nutrition (TPN)
* Glycemic control with regular insulin sliding scale
* Prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and stress ulcer
* HOB elevation and mouth care for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)

The patient's code status is full code, and her disposition is ICU.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 78-year-old female with a complex medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), myocardial infarction (MI), and peripheral vascular disease (PVD) with critical limb ischemia. The patient has been admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for management of her condition.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 400 mL, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O. Her arterial blood gas (ABG) results show a pH of 7.42, partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) of 36 mmHg, and partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) of 107 mmHg.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has a pericardial effusion with tamponade, which has been treated with drainage. Her left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) is 45-50%, and her right ventricular (RV) function is compromised.
* Hemodynamic: The patient's blood pressure is 100/50 mmHg, and her central venous pressure (CVP) is 10 mmHg. She is receiving vasopressor support with phenylephrine.
* Renal: The patient's creatinine level is 0.8 mg/dL, and her blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is 23 mg/dL.
* Hepatic: The patient's alanine aminotransferase (ALT) level is 138 IU/L, and her aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level is 62 IU/L.
* Infection: The patient has a fever of 101.3°F, and her white blood cell (WBC) count is trending up. Her sputum culture is positive for gram-negative rods (GNR) and gram-positive cocci (GPC). She is receiving antibiotic therapy with vancomycin, aztreonam, and ciprofloxacin.
* Nutritional: The patient is receiving total parenteral nutrition (TPN) and has a serum albumin level of 2.1 g/dL.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but she may require further weaning from mechanical ventilation.
* Cardiovascular instability: The patient's cardiac function is compromised, and she may require further management with vasopressors and inotropes.
* Infection: The patient has a positive sputum culture and may require further antibiotic therapy.
* Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and she may require further management with diuretics and hemodialysis.
* Hepatic dysfunction: The patient's liver function tests (LFTs) are abnormal, and she may require further management with lactulose and rifaximin.
* Nutritional deficiencies: The patient is receiving TPN, but she may require further nutritional support with enteral nutrition.

The patient's code status is full code, and her disposition is ICU.

Summary:

The patient is a 78-year-old female with a history of COPD, who presented with an anterior MI and failed PCI on a tight proximal lesion. She underwent pacemaker placement, which was complicated by RV perforation and right leg ischemia. The patient is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation, with a small pericardial effusion and mild tamponade. She has a fever, and her WBC count is trending up. She is also experiencing respiratory failure, with a CXR showing a left retrocardiac opacity and sputum growing GNR and GPC.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's fever and WBC count trending up suggest the possibility of sepsis, which could lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
2. Pericardial Tamponade: The patient's small pericardial effusion and mild tamponade could worsen, leading to cardiac tamponade and potentially life-threatening cardiac arrhythmias.
3. Right Leg Ischemia: The patient's right leg ischemia could progress, leading to gangrene and potential limb loss.
4. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure could worsen, leading to respiratory arrest and potentially life-threatening complications.
5. Pneumonia: The patient's CXR showing a left retrocardiac opacity and sputum growing GNR and GPC suggest the possibility of pneumonia, which could worsen her respiratory failure.
6. Cardiac Complications: The patient's history of MI and failed PCI on a tight proximal lesion make her at risk for cardiac complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias, cardiac tamponade, and cardiac failure.
7. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension could worsen, leading to organ dysfunction and failure.
8. Electrolyte Imbalance: The patient's electrolyte imbalance, particularly hypokalemia, could worsen, leading to cardiac arrhythmias and potentially life-threatening complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antibiotics and monitor the patient's response to treatment.
2. Wean the patient off Neo and consider stress dose steroids if necessary.
3. Monitor the patient's WBC count and fever curve, and consider repeat blood cultures and urine cultures.
4. Continue respiratory support and monitor the patient's oxygen saturation and respiratory status.
5. Monitor the patient's cardiac status, including her cardiac rhythm and blood pressure.
6. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and correct any imbalances.
7. Consider repeat echocardiogram to monitor the patient's pericardial effusion and cardiac function.
8. Consider consulting a cardiologist or intensivist to assist with the patient's care.

   placement. Repeat ECHO showed trivial effusion and no e/o tamponade.

   - trend CK

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 78-year-old female with a complex medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), acute myocardial infarction (AMI), and peripheral vascular disease (PVD) with critical limb ischemia. The patient has undergone several interventions, including pacemaker placement, left SFA thrombectomy, and right femoral endarterectomy.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Cardiovascular: The patient has a pacemaker in place, which was complicated by right ventricular (RV) perforation. The patient has also had a myocardial infarction and is on medical management.
* Respiratory: The patient is intubated and has a diagnosis of acute exacerbation of COPD. The patient has pneumonia and is on mechanical ventilation with a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute and a tidal volume of 400 mL.
* Renal: The patient has acute kidney injury (AKI) with a creatinine level of 1.0 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 23 mg/dL.
* Hematology: The patient has a white blood cell count (WBC) of 23.8 K/uL and a platelet count of 149 K/uL.
* Neurological: The patient has a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 15 and is able to follow simple commands.

The patient's medications include:

* Antibiotics: Aztreonam and ciprofloxacin
* Vasopressors: Dopamine and norepinephrine
* Diuretics: Furosemide
* Anti-inflammatory: Methylprednisolone
* Anticoagulants: Warfarin and aspirin

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 23 mg/dL
* Creatinine: 1.0 mg/dL
* White blood cell count (WBC): 23.8 K/uL
* Platelet count: 149 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 10.2 g/dL
* Hematocrit: 36.4%
* Sodium: 140 mmol/L
* Potassium: 4.6 mmol/L
* Chloride: 105 mmol/L
* Carbon dioxide: 32 mmol/L

The patient's radiological studies show:

* Chest X-ray (CXR): The patient has a left retrocardiac opacity and a right hilum opacity.
* Computed tomography (CT) scan: The patient has a diagnosis of pneumonia and a right pulmonary embolism.

The patient's diagnosis is as follows:

* Impaired skin integrity
* Sepsis without organ dysfunction
* Pericardial effusion with tamponade
* Peripheral vascular disease (PVD) with critical limb ischemia
* Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) with acute exacerbation
* Myocardial infarction, acute (AMI)
* Right ventricular (RV) perforation

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Antibiotics: Aztreonam and ciprofloxacin
* Vasopressors: Dopamine and norepinephrine
* Diuretics: Furosemide
* Anti-inflammatory: Methylprednisolone
* Anticoagulants: Warfarin and aspirin
* Pain management: Fentanyl and morphine
* Respiratory support: Mechanical ventilation
* Cardiovascular support: Inotropes and vasopressors
* Renal support: Dialysis

The patient's prognosis is guarded due to the complexity of their medical condition and the presence of multiple organ dysfunction.

   WITH ACUTE EXACERBATION
 MYOCARDIAL INFARCTION, ACUTE (AMI, STEMI, NSTEMI)
   78 yo F with COPD presents with anterior MI and failed PCI on a tight
   proximal lesion currently on medical management, s/p pacemaker
   placement complicated by RV perforation and right leg ischemia.
   HAP : WBC trending down, afebrile overnight. Pt neo was weaned off
   yesterday. CXR left retrocardiac opacity and sputum growing
   pseudomonas. UA neg, blood cx NGTD.
   - narrow abx to aztronam/cipro, await sensitivities
   - d/c vanco
   -maintain MAPs>60
   - f/u blood cx and urine cx
   - daily CXR (PA/Lat when stable)
   - monitor fever curve and trend WBC
   RV PERFORATION: Pt with tamponade after perforation of RV during pacer
   placement. Repeat ECHO showed trivial effusion and no e/o tamponade.
   Drain was removed [**7-26**]. Hct stable overnight.
   - Hct check q12
   - Active T&S
   - cont to monitor hemodynamics closely
   - consider repeat ECHO if worsens
   .
   RIGHT LEG ISCHEMIA: Distal pulses were lost after placement of right
   femoral a-line. s/p left SFA thrombectomy, femoral endarterectomy,
   right fasciotomy. +dopplerable pulses post-procedure. CK wnl
   - appreciate vascular recs
   - cont to check dopplers
   - monitor wound site
   - trend CK
   - no anti-coagulation given RV perforation
   RHYTHM: H/O paroxysmal Afib but presents with slow afib and AV
   dissociation.  Pt underwent pacemaker placement that was complicated by
   RV perforation. CXR neg for PTX
   - appreciate EP recs
   - cont abx as above, levolox x10d at d/c
   - cont to monitor on tele
   - will need PA/Lat when stable
   CORONARIES: Pt transferred for NSTEMI and is s/p ccath that  focal LAD
   lesions that could not be intevened . Pt was being medically managed
   and stable.  BP meds were held secondary to hypotension.
   - cont ASA and plavix given stable Hct
   - holding coreg, Imdur and amlodipine
   .
   PUMP: EF 45-50%,  Pt was positive 350 in last 24hrs. LOS positive 7.5.
   CXR shows worsening edema. Received 40mg IV lasix overnight.
   - I/O with goal of  -1L, IV lasix 40mg this AM
   - hold  Coreg
   - daily CXR
   .
   RESPIRATORY FAILURE: Pt intubated after tamponade. Last ABG
   7.38/38/146/23. Pt resp status complicated by HAP, COPD and now
   worsening pulmonary edema. RISBI improved from yesterday to 120 from
   300
s. Pt more reactive,
   . Pt seen by pulm and rec cont current regimen. Pt with likely
   pneumonia. Management as above.
   . Currently resp status is stable. Pt with COPD and was on prednisone
   for COPD exacerbation.
   - Cont current vent setting, wean as tolerated, consider trial of CPAP
   - cont IV steroids (methylpred 40mg)
   - cont albuterol/ipratropium Q4
   - daily CXR today
   - f/u sputum cx
   -f/u pulm recs
   .
   COPD: Pt on methylpred for flare. Pulm was consulted prior to RV
   perforation. Recommended non-con CT for eval for right hilum. Question
   as to whether pt truly as COPD or other process given recent worsening
   over the last year.
   - cont methylpred
   - cont albuterol/ipratropium
   - non-con CT when stable
   .
   HTN: Pt hypotensive this AM. BP meds were d/c overnight.
   - holding BP meds for now
   .
   ACCESS: CVL placed by IR [**7-27**], brachial A-line
   FEN: NPO,  TF, replete lytes prn

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 78-year-old female with a complex medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), myocardial infarction (MI), and peripheral vascular disease (PVD) with critical limb ischemia. She was admitted to the ICU with sepsis, pericardial effusion with tamponade, and airway compromise.

The patient underwent several procedures, including pacemaker placement, which was complicated by RV perforation and right leg ischemia. She also had a left SFA thrombectomy, femoral endarterectomy, and right fasciotomy.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: intubated and mechanically ventilated, with a recent improvement in respiratory index score (RISBI) from 300 to 120.
* Cardiovascular status: tachycardic, with a heart rate of 75 beats per minute, and a blood pressure of 132/79 mmHg.
* Hemodynamic monitoring: the patient is receiving vasopressors to maintain a mean arterial pressure (MAP) greater than 60 mmHg.
* Renal function: the patient has a creatinine level of 1.0 mg/dL, and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 23 mg/dL.
* Liver function: the patient has a total bilirubin level of 0.9 mg/dL, and an alkaline phosphatase level of 97 IU/L.
* Coagulation status: the patient has a prothrombin time (PT) of 14.1 seconds, a partial thromboplastin time (PTT) of 32.1 seconds, and an international normalized ratio (INR) of 1.2.
* Wound care: the patient has a right leg wound that is being monitored and managed with dressings and antibiotics.
* Medications: the patient is receiving a range of medications, including vasopressors, antibiotics, anticoagulants, and steroids.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure: the patient's respiratory status is compromised, and she may require continued mechanical ventilation and respiratory support.
* Cardiovascular instability: the patient's cardiovascular status is tenuous, and she may require continued vasopressor support and monitoring.
* Sepsis: the patient has a history of sepsis, and may be at risk for further complications, including organ dysfunction and death.
* Wound complications: the patient's right leg wound may become infected or develop complications, such as necrosis or gangrene.
* Hemodynamic instability: the patient's blood pressure may fluctuate, and she may require continued monitoring and support.
* Renal dysfunction: the patient's creatinine level is elevated, and she may be at risk for further renal dysfunction or failure.
* Liver dysfunction: the patient's liver function tests are abnormal, and she may be at risk for further liver dysfunction or failure.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires continued close monitoring and management to prevent further complications and ensure optimal outcomes.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 78-year-old female with a complex medical history, including:

* Myocardial Infarction (MI) with failed PCI on a tight proximal lesion
* Right ventricular (RV) perforation during pacemaker placement
* Right leg ischemia
* Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) with acute exacerbation
* Pneumonia
* Hypertension
* Impaired skin integrity
* Sepsis without organ dysfunction
* Pericardial effusion with tamponade
* Peripheral vascular disease (PVD) with critical limb ischemia

The patient's current status is as follows:

* Respiratory: Intubated, receiving mechanical ventilation, and on antibiotics for pneumonia. The patient's respiratory status is stable, but there is a risk of worsening pulmonary edema.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has a pacemaker in place, and there is a risk of further cardiac complications due to the RV perforation.
* Renal: The patient has impaired renal function, and there is a risk of worsening kidney injury due to the use of nephrotoxic medications.
* Hemodynamic: The patient is hypotensive, and there is a risk of further hypotension due to the use of vasodilators.
* Infectious: The patient has pneumonia and is receiving antibiotics, but there is a risk of further infection due to the presence of a central line and other invasive devices.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Cardiac arrhythmias due to the pacemaker and RV perforation
* Pneumonia worsening due to the patient's underlying COPD and immunosuppressive therapy
* Sepsis worsening due to the patient's underlying medical conditions and invasive devices
* Renal failure due to the patient's impaired renal function and use of nephrotoxic medications
* Respiratory failure due to the patient's underlying COPD and worsening pulmonary edema
* Bleeding due to the patient's coagulopathy and use of anticoagulant medications

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Continuous monitoring of vital signs and laboratory results
* Adjustment of medications to manage the patient's underlying medical conditions
* Close monitoring of the patient's respiratory and cardiac status
* Consideration of further diagnostic testing, such as a non-contrast CT scan, to evaluate the patient's right hilum
* Discussion of code status and goals of care with the patient's family

Overall, the patient's complex medical condition and multiple comorbidities make her at high risk for further complications and require close monitoring and aggressive management.

   Assessment and Plan
 IMPAIRED SKIN INTEGRITY
 SEPSIS WITHOUT ORGAN DYSFUNCTION
 PERICARDIAL EFFUSION WITH TAMPONADE
 PERIPHERAL VASCULAR DISEASE (PVD) WITH CRITICAL LIMB ISCHEMIA
 AIRWAY, INABILITY TO PROTECT (RISK FOR ASPIRATION, ALTERED GAG,
   AIRWAY CLEARANCE, COUGH)
 CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE PULMONARY DISEASE (COPD, BRONCHITIS, EMPHYSEMA)
   WITH ACUTE EXACERBATION
 MYOCARDIAL INFARCTION, ACUTE (AMI, STEMI, NSTEMI)
   78 yo F with COPD presents with anterior MI and failed PCI on a tight
   proximal lesion currently on medical management, s/p pacemaker
   placement complicated by RV perforation and right leg ischemia.
   # HAP : WBC stablely elev, afebrile overnight. CXR left retrocardiac
   opacity and sputum growing pseudomonas pansensitive. Changed to
   meropenem. UA neg, blood cx NGTD.
   - cont abx  meropenem day #3 (monitor for allergic reaction given PCN
   allergy)
   - cont vanco given device placement for total of 7 days and then
   transition to levofloxacin
   - vanc trough this AM and re-dose if <20
   - maintain MAPs>60
   - f/u blood cx and urine cx
   - daily CXR (PA/Lat when stable)
   - monitor fever curve and trend WBC
   # RV PERFORATION: Pt with tamponade after perforation of RV during
   pacer placement. Repeat ECHO showed trivial effusion and no e/o
   tamponade. Drain was removed [**7-26**]. Hct stable overnight.
   -daily Hct
   - Active T&S
   - cont to monitor hemodynamics closely
   .
   # RIGHT LEG ISCHEMIA: Distal pulses were lost after placement of right
   femoral a-line. s/p left SFA thrombectomy, femoral endarterectomy,
   right fasciotomy. +dopplerable pulses post-procedure. CK wnl
   - appreciate vascular recs
   - cont to check dopplers
   - monitor wound site
   - no anti-coagulation given RV perforation
   # RHYTHM: H/O paroxysmal Afib but presents with slow afib and AV
   dissociation.  Pt underwent pacemaker placement that was complicated by
   RV perforation. CXR neg for PTX. Pt now in a-fib with RVR. Treated with
   metoprolol, but still not rate controlled.  Limited in titrating up BB
   by pressures and resp status
   - appreciate EP recs
   - begin amiodarone today
   - cont metoprolol 37.5 mg TID for now
   - will cont to hold on anticoagulation, espec since pt has not been on
   anticoag for p-afib in the past
   - cont abx as above, levoflox x10d at d/c
   - cont to monitor on tele
   - will need PA/Lat when stable
   # CORONARIES: Pt transferred for NSTEMI and is s/p ccath that  focal
   LAD lesions that could not be intevened . Pt was being medically
   managed and stable.  BP meds were held secondary to hypotension.
   - cont ASA and plavix given stable Hct
   - holding coreg, Imdur and amlodipine
   .
   # PUMP: EF 45-50%,  Pt was started on lasix gtt with good UOP. -2.5L in
   last 24hrs.  Currently off lasix gtt and autodiuresis.
   - I/O with goal of  -1-1.5L
   - f/u CXR
   - daily CXR
   .
   # RESPIRATORY FAILURE: Pt intubated after tamponade. Pt resp status
   complicated by HAP, COPD and pulmonary edema.  Pt with effective
   diuresis yesterday. Pt more reactive.
   . Pt seen by pulm and rec cont current regimen. Pt with likely
   pneumonia. Management as above.
   . Currently resp status is stable. Pt with COPD and was on prednisone
   for COPD exacerbation.
   - Attempt to wean and possibly extubate today
   - cont IV steroids (methylpred 40mg)
   - cont albuterol/ipratropium Q4
   - daily CXR today
   .
   # COPD: Pt on methylpred for flare. Pulm was consulted prior to RV
   perforation. Recommended non-con CT for eval for right hilum. Question
   as to whether pt truly as COPD or other process given recent worsening
   over the last year.
   - cont methylpred
   - cont albuterol/ipratropium
   - non-con CT when stable
   .
   # HTN: Pt hypotensive overnight likely from overdiuresis.
   - cont metoprolol for now as above
   .
   ACCESS: R IJ placed by IR [**7-27**],  radial a-line
   FEN: NPO,  TF, replete lytes prn
   CONTACT: [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Known lastname **] [**Telephone/Fax (5) 7029**]
   CODE: FULL (reversed DNR/DNI for procedure, will need to discuss
   options and goals of care with family)
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:  Regular insulin sliding scale

   agree with the above note and plans.
   I have also reviewed the notes of Dr(s). [**Name (NI) 7030**].
   I would add the following remarks:
   History
   intubated.  Sedation lessened.  Problems with afib with rapid response
   assoc with drop in BP and intermittent neo.
   on Meripenim and vanc with WBC 22.3.
   Good diuresis with lasix with Cr 1.1.
   Medical Decision Making
   Will add Amiodarone to try to restore NSR.
   Will try to move to extubation over next 48 hrs.
   Would avoid high dose beta blocker with severe COPD.

   tamponade. Drain was removed [**7-26**]. Hct stable overnight.

   - Active T&S
   - cont to monitor hemodynamics closely
   .
   # RIGHT LEG ISCHEMIA: Distal pulses were lost after placement of right
   femoral a-line. s/p left SFA thrombectomy, femoral endarterectomy,
   right fasciotomy. +dopplerable pulses post-procedure. CK wnl
   - appreciate vascular recs
   - cont to check dopplers
   - monitor wound site
   - no anti-coagulation given RV perforation
   # RHYTHM: H/O paroxysmal Afib but presents with slow afib and AV
   dissociation.  Pt underwent pacemaker placement that was complicated by
   RV perforation. CXR neg for PTX. Pt now in a-fib with RVR. Treated with
   metoprolol, but still not rate controlled.  Limited in titrating up BB
   by pressures and resp status
   - appreciate EP recs
   - begin amiodarone today
   - cont metoprolol 37.5 mg TID for now
   - will cont to hold on anticoagulation, espec since pt has not been on
   anticoag for p-afib in the past
   - cont abx as above, levoflox x10d at d/c
   - cont to monitor on tele
   - will need PA/Lat when stable
   # CORONARIES: Pt transferred for NSTEMI and is s/p ccath that  focal
   LAD lesions that could not be intevened . Pt was being medically
   managed and stable.  BP meds were held secondary to hypotension.
   - cont ASA and plavix given stable Hct
   - holding coreg, Imdur and amlodipine
   .
   # PUMP: EF 45-50%,  Pt was started on lasix gtt with good UOP. -2.5L in
   last 24hrs.  Currently off lasix gtt and autodiuresis.
   - I/O with goal of  -1-1.5L
   - f/u CXR
   - daily CXR
   .
   # RESPIRATORY FAILURE: Pt intubated after tamponade. Pt resp status
   complicated by HAP, COPD and pulmonary edema.  Pt with effective
   diuresis yesterday. Pt more reactive.
   . Pt seen by pulm and rec cont current regimen. Pt with likely
   pneumonia. Management as above.
   . Currently resp status is stable. Pt with COPD and was on prednisone
   for COPD exacerbation.
   - Attempt to wean and possibly extubate today
   - cont IV steroids (methylpred 40mg)

   as to whether pt truly as COPD or other process given recent worsening
   over the last year.
   - cont methylpred
   - cont albuterol/ipratropium
   - non-con CT when stable

Based on the provided medical progress note, the patient is a 78-year-old female with a complex medical history, including:

1. Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) with acute exacerbation
2. Anterior Myocardial Infarction (AMI) with failed PCI
3. Right leg ischemia with distal pulses lost
4. RV perforation with tamponade
5. Pseudomonas pneumonia
6. Hypertension
7. Hyperglycemia
8. Impaired skin integrity
9. Sepsis without organ dysfunction

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: Intubated, with effective diuresis and stable respiratory status
* Cardiac status: In atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, with a history of RV perforation and tamponade
* Hemodynamic status: Hypotensive, with a blood pressure of 64/37 mmHg
* Renal status: Good diuresis with lasix, with a creatinine of 1.1 mg/dL
* Wound status: Right leg ischemia with distal pulses lost, with a wound that is being monitored
* Infection status: Pseudomonas pneumonia, with sputum growing pansensitive pseudomonas

The patient's current treatment plan includes:

* Antibiotics: Meropenem for pneumonia, with a plan to transition to levofloxacin
* Vasopressors: Norepinephrine for hypotension
* Diuretics: Lasix for fluid overload
* Sedation: Propofol for sedation
* Pain management: Morphine for pain
* Anticoagulation: Holding anticoagulation due to RV perforation

Potential medical complications that could arise include:

* Respiratory failure: Given the patient's COPD and pneumonia, there is a risk of respiratory failure, particularly if the patient's oxygenation and ventilation needs are not adequately managed.
* Cardiac complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response increases the risk of cardiac complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias, heart failure, and cardiac arrest.
* Renal complications: The patient's hypotension and fluid overload increase the risk of renal complications, such as acute kidney injury and chronic kidney disease.
* Wound complications: The patient's right leg ischemia and wound increase the risk of wound complications, such as infection, necrosis, and amputation.
* Infection: The patient's pneumonia and sepsis increase the risk of infection, particularly if the patient's immune system is compromised.

Based on the patient's complex medical history and current condition, it is essential to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status to prevent potential complications and ensure optimal care.

 IMPAIRED SKIN INTEGRITY
 SEPSIS WITHOUT ORGAN DYSFUNCTION
 PERICARDIAL EFFUSION WITH TAMPONADE
 PERIPHERAL VASCULAR DISEASE (PVD) WITH CRITICAL LIMB ISCHEMIA
 AIRWAY, INABILITY TO PROTECT (RISK FOR ASPIRATION, ALTERED GAG,
   AIRWAY CLEARANCE, COUGH)
 CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE PULMONARY DISEASE (COPD, BRONCHITIS, EMPHYSEMA)
   WITH ACUTE EXACERBATION
 MYOCARDIAL INFARCTION, ACUTE (AMI, STEMI, NSTEMI)
   78 yo F with COPD presents with anterior MI and failed PCI on a tight
   proximal lesion currently on medical management, s/p pacemaker
   placement complicated by RV perforation and right leg ischemia.
   # HAP : WBC stablely elev, afebrile overnight. CXR left retrocardiac
   opacity and sputum growing pseudomonas pansensitive. Changed to
   meropenem. UA neg, blood cx NGTD.
   - cont abx  meropenem day #3 (monitor for allergic reaction given PCN
   allergy)
   - cont vanco given device placement for total of 7 days and then
   transition to levofloxacin
   - vanc trough this AM and re-dose if <20
   - maintain MAPs>60
   - f/u blood cx and urine cx
   - daily CXR (PA/Lat when stable)
   - monitor fever curve and trend WBC
   # RV PERFORATION: Pt with tamponade after perforation of RV during
   pacer placement. Repeat ECHO showed trivial effusion and no e/o
   tamponade. Drain was removed [**7-26**]. Hct stable overnight.
   -daily Hct
   - Active T&S
   - cont to monitor hemodynamics closely
   .
   # RIGHT LEG ISCHEMIA: Distal pulses were lost after placement of right
   femoral a-line. s/p left SFA thrombectomy, femoral endarterectomy,
   right fasciotomy. +dopplerable pulses post-procedure. CK wnl
   - appreciate vascular recs
   - cont to check dopplers
   - monitor wound site
   - no anti-coagulation given RV perforation
   # RHYTHM: H/O paroxysmal Afib but presents with slow afib and AV
   dissociation.  Pt underwent pacemaker placement that was complicated by
   RV perforation. CXR neg for PTX. Pt now in a-fib with RVR. Treated with
   metoprolol, but still not rate controlled.  Limited in titrating up BB
   by pressures and resp status
   - appreciate EP recs
   - begin amiodarone today
   - cont metoprolol 37.5 mg TID for now
   - will cont to hold on anticoagulation, espec since pt has not been on
   anticoag for p-afib in the past
   - cont abx as above, levoflox x10d at d/c
   - cont to monitor on tele
   - will need PA/Lat when stable
   # CORONARIES: Pt transferred for NSTEMI and is s/p ccath that  focal
   LAD lesions that could not be intevened . Pt was being medically
   managed and stable.  BP meds were held secondary to hypotension.
   - cont ASA and plavix given stable Hct
   - holding coreg, Imdur and amlodipine
   .
   # PUMP: EF 45-50%,  Pt was started on lasix gtt with good UOP. -2.5L in
   last 24hrs.  Currently off lasix gtt and autodiuresis.
   - I/O with goal of  -1-1.5L
   - f/u CXR
   - daily CXR
   .
   # RESPIRATORY FAILURE: Pt intubated after tamponade. Pt resp status
   complicated by HAP, COPD and pulmonary edema.  Pt with effective
   diuresis yesterday. Pt more reactive.
   . Pt seen by pulm and rec cont current regimen. Pt with likely
   pneumonia. Management as above.
   . Currently resp status is stable. Pt with COPD and was on prednisone
   for COPD exacerbation.
   - Attempt to wean and possibly extubate today
   - cont IV steroids (methylpred 40mg)
   - cont albuterol/ipratropium Q4
   - daily CXR today
   .
   # COPD: Pt on methylpred for flare. Pulm was consulted prior to RV
   perforation. Recommended non-con CT for eval for right hilum. Question
   as to whether pt truly as COPD or other process given recent worsening
   over the last year.
   - cont methylpred
   - cont albuterol/ipratropium
   - non-con CT when stable
   .
   # HTN: Pt hypotensive overnight likely from overdiuresis.
   - cont metoprolol for now as above
   .

   FEN: NPO,  TF, replete lytes prn

Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 78-year-old female with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), who presented with an anterior myocardial infarction (MI) and failed percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). She was transferred to the intensive care unit (ICU) for further management. The patient developed RV perforation during pacemaker placement, which was complicated by tamponade. She also developed right leg ischemia, which was treated with a left SFA thrombectomy, femoral endarterectomy, and right fasciotomy.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation. She has a history of COPD and is being treated for acute exacerbation.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has a pacemaker in place, and her ejection fraction is 45-50%. She is being treated for hypertension and hypotension.
* Neurological: The patient has a history of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation (AFib) and is currently in a-fib with rapid ventricular response (RVR).
* Renal: The patient has a history of chronic kidney disease (CKD) and is being treated for acute kidney injury (AKI).
* Hematological: The patient has a history of anemia and is being treated with erythropoietin.
* Infectious: The patient has a urinary tract infection (UTI) and is being treated with antibiotics.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's UTI and respiratory failure increase the risk of developing sepsis.
2. Cardiac Arrest: The patient's history of AFib and RVR, as well as her current condition, increase the risk of cardiac arrest.
3. Respiratory Failure: The patient's COPD and pneumonia increase the risk of respiratory failure.
4. Renal Failure: The patient's AKI and CKD increase the risk of renal failure.
5. Neurological Complications: The patient's history of AFib and RVR increase the risk of neurological complications, such as stroke or transient ischemic attack (TIA).
6. Infectious Complications: The patient's UTI and respiratory failure increase the risk of developing infectious complications, such as pneumonia or sepsis.
7. Bleeding Complications: The patient's anticoagulation therapy increases the risk of bleeding complications.

Plan:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results closely.
2. Continue to treat the patient's UTI and pneumonia with antibiotics.
3. Continue to manage the patient's hypertension and hypotension with medication.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust her treatment plan accordingly.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust her treatment plan accordingly.
6. Consider weaning the patient off mechanical ventilation and extubating her when possible.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's blood glucose levels and adjust her treatment plan accordingly.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's platelet count and adjust her treatment plan accordingly.
9. Consider using stress ulcer prophylaxis to prevent gastrointestinal bleeding.
10. Consider using DVT prophylaxis to prevent deep vein thrombosis.

 IMPAIRED SKIN INTEGRITY
 SEPSIS WITHOUT ORGAN DYSFUNCTION
 PERICARDIAL EFFUSION WITH TAMPONADE
 PERIPHERAL VASCULAR DISEASE (PVD) WITH CRITICAL LIMB ISCHEMIA
 AIRWAY, INABILITY TO PROTECT (RISK FOR ASPIRATION, ALTERED GAG,
   AIRWAY CLEARANCE, COUGH)
 CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE PULMONARY DISEASE (COPD, BRONCHITIS, EMPHYSEMA)
   WITH ACUTE EXACERBATION
 MYOCARDIAL INFARCTION, ACUTE (AMI, STEMI, NSTEMI)
   78 yo F with COPD presents with anterior MI and failed PCI on a tight
   proximal lesion currently on medical management, s/p pacemaker
   placement complicated by RV perforation and right leg ischemia.
   HAP : WBC stable, afebrile overnight. CXR left retrocardiac opacity and
   sputum growing pseudomonas pansensitive. Changed to meropenem. UA neg,
   blood cx NGTD.
   - cont abx  meropenem day #3 (monitor for allergic reaction given PCN
   allergy)
   - cont vanco given device placement for total of 7 days
   - vanc trough this AM and re-dose if <20
   - maintain MAPs>60
   - f/u blood cx and urine cx
   - daily CXR (PA/Lat when stable)
   - monitor fever curve and trend WBC
   RV PERFORATION: Pt with tamponade after perforation of RV during pacer
   placement. Repeat ECHO showed trivial effusion and no e/o tamponade.
   Drain was removed [**7-26**]. Hct stable overnight.
   -daily Hct
   - Active T&S
   - cont to monitor hemodynamics closely
   .
   RIGHT LEG ISCHEMIA: Distal pulses were lost after placement of right
   femoral a-line. s/p left SFA thrombectomy, femoral endarterectomy,
   right fasciotomy. +dopplerable pulses post-procedure. CK wnl
   - appreciate vascular recs
   - cont to check dopplers
   - monitor wound site
   - no anti-coagulation given RV perforation
   RHYTHM: H/O paroxysmal Afib but presents with slow afib and AV
   dissociation.  Pt underwent pacemaker placement that was complicated by
   RV perforation. CXR neg for PTX. Pt now in a-fib with RVR. Treated with
   metoprolol, but still not rate controlled.  Limited in titrating up BB
   by pressures and resp status
   - appreciate EP recs
   - consider digoxin
   - cont metoprolol 25mg TID for now
   - cont abx as above, levolox x10d at d/c
   - cont to monitor on tele
   - will need PA/Lat when stable
   CORONARIES: Pt transferred for NSTEMI and is s/p ccath that  focal LAD
   lesions that could not be intevened . Pt was being medically managed
   and stable.  BP meds were held secondary to hypotension.
   - cont ASA and plavix given stable Hct
   - holding coreg, Imdur and amlodipine
   .
   PUMP: EF 45-50%,  Pt was started on lasix gtt with good UOP. -2.5L in
   last 24hrs.  Currently off lasix gtt and autodiuresis.
   - I/O with goal of  -1-1.5L
   - f/u CXR
   - daily CXR
   .
   RESPIRATORY FAILURE: Pt intubated after tamponade. Pt resp status
   complicated by HAP, COPD and pulmonary edema.  Pt with effective
   diuresis yesterday. Pt more reactive.
   . Pt seen by pulm and rec cont current regimen. Pt with likely
   pneumonia. Management as above.
   . Currently resp status is stable. Pt with COPD and was on prednisone
   for COPD exacerbation.
   - Cont current vent setting, wean as tolerated, consider trial of CPAP
   today
   - cont IV steroids (methylpred 40mg)
   - cont albuterol/ipratropium Q4
   - daily CXR today
   -f/u pulm recs
   - aim to extuate later today or tomorrow AM
   .
   COPD: Pt on methylpred for flare. Pulm was consulted prior to RV
   perforation. Recommended non-con CT for eval for right hilum. Question
   as to whether pt truly as COPD or other process given recent worsening
   over the last year.
   - cont methylpred
   - cont albuterol/ipratropium
   - non-con CT when stable
   .
   HTN: Pt hypotensive overnight likely from overdiuresis.
   - cont metoprolol for now as above
   .
   ACCESS: R IJ placed by IR [**7-27**],  radial a-line
   FEN: NPO,  TF, replete lytes prn
   CONTACT: [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Known lastname **] [**Telephone/Fax (5) 7029**]

   options and goals of care with family)

 IMPAIRED SKIN INTEGRITY
 SEPSIS WITHOUT ORGAN DYSFUNCTION
 PERICARDIAL EFFUSION WITH TAMPONADE
 PERIPHERAL VASCULAR DISEASE (PVD) WITH CRITICAL LIMB ISCHEMIA
 AIRWAY, INABILITY TO PROTECT (RISK FOR ASPIRATION, ALTERED GAG,
   AIRWAY CLEARANCE, COUGH)
 CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE PULMONARY DISEASE (COPD, BRONCHITIS, EMPHYSEMA)
   WITH ACUTE EXACERBATION
 MYOCARDIAL INFARCTION, ACUTE (AMI, STEMI, NSTEMI)
   78 yo F with COPD presents with anterior MI and failed PCI on a tight
   proximal lesion currently on medical management, s/p pacemaker
   placement complicated by RV perforation and right leg ischemia.
   HAP : WBC stable, afebrile overnight. CXR left retrocardiac opacity and
   sputum growing pseudomonas pansensitive. Changed to meropenem. UA neg,
   blood cx NGTD.
   - cont abx  meropenem day #3 (monitor for allergic reaction given PCN
   allergy)
   - cont vanco given device placement for total of 7 days
   - vanc trough this AM and re-dose if <20
   - maintain MAPs>60
   - f/u blood cx and urine cx
   - daily CXR (PA/Lat when stable)
   - monitor fever curve and trend WBC
   RV PERFORATION: Pt with tamponade after perforation of RV during pacer
   placement. Repeat ECHO showed trivial effusion and no e/o tamponade.
   Drain was removed [**7-26**]. Hct stable overnight.
   -daily Hct
   - Active T&S
   - cont to monitor hemodynamics closely
   .
   RIGHT LEG ISCHEMIA: Distal pulses were lost after placement of right
   femoral a-line. s/p left SFA thrombectomy, femoral endarterectomy,
   right fasciotomy. +dopplerable pulses post-procedure. CK wnl
   - appreciate vascular recs
   - cont to check dopplers
   - monitor wound site
   - no anti-coagulation given RV perforation
   RHYTHM: H/O paroxysmal Afib but presents with slow afib and AV
   dissociation.  Pt underwent pacemaker placement that was complicated by
   RV perforation. CXR neg for PTX. Pt now in a-fib with RVR. Treated with
   metoprolol, but still not rate controlled.  Limited in titrating up BB
   by pressures and resp status
   - appreciate EP recs
   - consider digoxin
   - cont metoprolol 25mg TID for now
   - cont abx as above, levolox x10d at d/c
   - cont to monitor on tele
   - will need PA/Lat when stable
   CORONARIES: Pt transferred for NSTEMI and is s/p ccath that  focal LAD
   lesions that could not be intevened . Pt was being medically managed
   and stable.  BP meds were held secondary to hypotension.
   - cont ASA and plavix given stable Hct
   - holding coreg, Imdur and amlodipine
   .
   PUMP: EF 45-50%,  Pt was started on lasix gtt with good UOP. -2.5L in
   last 24hrs.  Currently off lasix gtt and autodiuresis.
   - I/O with goal of  -1-1.5L
   - f/u CXR
   - daily CXR
   .
   RESPIRATORY FAILURE: Pt intubated after tamponade. Pt resp status
   complicated by HAP, COPD and pulmonary edema.  Pt with effective
   diuresis yesterday. Pt more reactive.
   . Pt seen by pulm and rec cont current regimen. Pt with likely
   pneumonia. Management as above.
   . Currently resp status is stable. Pt with COPD and was on prednisone
   for COPD exacerbation.
   - Cont current vent setting, wean as tolerated, consider trial of CPAP
   today
   - cont IV steroids (methylpred 40mg)
   - cont albuterol/ipratropium Q4
   - daily CXR today
   -f/u pulm recs
   - aim to extuate later today or tomorrow AM
   .
   COPD: Pt on methylpred for flare. Pulm was consulted prior to RV
   perforation. Recommended non-con CT for eval for right hilum. Question
   as to whether pt truly as COPD or other process given recent worsening
   over the last year.
   - cont methylpred
   - cont albuterol/ipratropium
   - non-con CT when stable
   .
   HTN: Pt hypotensive overnight likely from overdiuresis.
   - cont metoprolol for now as above
   .
